> A second issue related to this list is that, because evolution tends to =
quickly select away mutations that deeply change representations, it is lik=
ely a good idea to have something like the genomic diversity protection in =
NEAT. Because recent work has shown that phenotypic/behavioral diversity is=
 more effective than genotypic diversity, many people may be switching to p=
henotypic diversity and abandoning genomic diversity: this work suggests th=
at both may be important. For example, mutations that affect a representati=
on deeply may initially hurt the organism's ability to do something behavio=
rally different/interesting, for the same reason that such mutations hurts =
fitness (e.g. they cripple the organism). Protecting that innovation for a =
while may thus pay off.  

I haven't read your paper yet. But following you=
r argumentation, when profound differences in the genetic code have also a =
relatively large influence on the phenotype, protecting the phenotypic/beha=
vioral diversity should do the job!? 

> In other words, because selection =
will quickly work to eliminate deep changes, we should probably protect the=
m for a while if we want to see better representations emerge.  

I was won=
dering, whether it could be beneficial to protect phenotypic diversity in C=
PPNs (e.g. in HyperNEAT). Instead of measuring the similarity of the genome=
s, the similarity of the produced patterns could be used to determine which=
 individuals belong to which species. The idea is that relatively similar g=
enomes can nevertheless produce differing patterns. Separating them would a=
llow to better exploit the potential of the same genetic code.
